title: Small plane makes crash landing on U.S. 50 in Maryland, hitting a vehicle and injuring two people, officials say
text:
Two adults in the car were taken to a hospital with minor injuries after the crash, Brady said, and two people in the plane were evaluated for injuries and declined to be transported.

Maryland State Police said officers responded to eastbound Route 50 at Church Road when the plane crashed moments after taking off from the small airport. The cause of the crash hasn’t been determined, police said.

AD

Police identified the pilot as Julius Tolson Jr., 58, of Laurel, and his passenger as Michael Garrah, 57, of Columbia. Both are listed as “other owners” of the plane in the Federal Aviation Administration registry.

AD

A message to Tolson at a phone number in public records wasn’t returned. Contacted at the scene, Garrah declined to comment.

The plane’s registered owner, Derrick Early of Greenbelt, said he didn’t know what caused the aircraft to go down.

“Accidents like these, there’s an official investigation into it,” he said. “And so the goal is to figure out what happened.”

Eric Diprospero, 31, of Baltimore said he was headed to work in Annapolis with a colleague when “out of nowhere a plane appeared in the middle of the highway, and we struck it very hard.”

AD

“It was in front of us,” he said. “It was a split-second thing where it skidded right across the middle of the highway, and there was no time to react.”

Diprospero said that he was grateful for the fast response of authorities and that he and his co-worker suffered only minor cuts and bruises.

AD

“It’s just probably a miracle, right?” he said. “I’ve never been involved in a vehicle-plane crash before.”

The white and maroon aircraft sat on its belly in the inner median of the highway as ambulances and police cruisers swarmed the scene. What appeared to be the plane’s shorn-off wing was crumpled several yards away next to a silver sedan with a smashed front end and its doors flung open.

AD

From the archives: His F-16 lost its engine, then caught fire over Washington before crashing. And he lived to tell about it.

Prince George’s Fire Department spokesman Mike Yourishin said such plane crashes occur occasionally in the area.

“I’m counting our lucky stars it wasn’t worse,” he said.

Maryland State Police and the FAA are handling the investigation, he said.

Catherine L. Harvey was one of several residents and motorists who stopped along an overpass to take photos and observe the scene. Harvey, who has lived in Bowie for 12 years, stepped out onto her porch after hearing the ambulances and then headed to the overpass.

AD

She wasn’t surprised that the plane had crashed nearby. Another one had crashed into the woods along the highway about three years ago, she recalled.

AD

U.S. 50 is “pretty smooth and easy,” Harvey said. “It’s just nerve-racking when you come to the airport because of things like this, so I find myself looking up when I’m driving because I know the planes are coming in and going out.”

Residents Randy Smith and James Eason, standing on the overpass with Harvey, agreed.

“In the morning going down this way, it slows down about there,” Smith said, pointing to the wreckage below. “Back in the evening, it slows down. It’s kind of like a Bermuda Triangle.”

Eason said that his home is under a flight path for the airport and that crashes involving pilots in training are a constant worry. Eason said Thursday’s crash was at least the third he can remember in his seven years living in the area.

AD

AD

A woman at the office of Freeway Airport declined to comment on the crash. A website for the airport said it has been “offering flight instruction, pilot services and aircraft maintenance in the Baltimore-Washington area for over 50 years.”

It touts itself as “one of the few rural areas left in Maryland’s Prince George’s County” to offer “an ideal and relaxed atmosphere for flight lessons.”

Several lanes were closed as emergency crews worked at the scene Thursday. Delays on U.S. 50 extended for more than a mile in each direction.

From 2017: Small plane crashed near airport in Bowie

AD
description: The crash occurred near Freeway Airport in Bowie, authorities said.
